Award.AbstractNarration:
In recent work with Zoltan Szabo, the principal investigator constructed invariants for three- and four-dimensional spaces, called Heegaard Floer homology. In further joint work with Robert Lipshitz and Dylan Thurston, these invariants are extended down, to define bordered Floer homology. Bordered Floer homology gives invariants for two-dimensional surfaces and three-dimensional spaces with two-dimensional boundary. These bordered invariants shed light on Heegaard Floer homology in its original setting. In particular, they can be used to give conceptual calculations of certain Heegaard Floer invariants for closed manifolds. The project aims to understands the invariants better, extending the "bordered theory" to a broader context.



The introduction of equations with origins in mathematical physics has lead to great advances in our understanding of the topological properties of three and four-dimensional spaces over the past twenty-five years. Further progress in this area is facilitated by an alternative, more geometric understanding of the data derived from these equations, known as "Heegaard Floer homology", developed by the investigator in collaboration with Zoltan Szabo. This three and four-dimensional story can be extended to cover two-dimensional objects, as well, in a a new theory, "bordered Floer homology", developed by the investigator in collaboration with Robert Lipshitz and Dylan Thurston. The proposal aims to further develop both of these tools and apply them to study topological questions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
"Heegaard Floer homology" is an invariant for low-dimensional manifolds (three- and four-dimensional spaces) which was defined by the PI in joint work with Zoltan Szabo. Work of the PI in collaboration with Robert Lipshitz and Dylan Thurston introduces new structure, combined with new computational techniques for this invariant, called "bordered Floer homology".

The project further develops bordered Floer homology, and its interactions with Heegaard Floer homology. One application of these developments is to "knot theory", the study of knotted curves in three-dimensional space. Heegaard Floer homology can be adapted to give an invariant for such knots, called "knot Floer homology". Bordered techniques can be used to give effective computations of knot Floer homology, a development which was pioneered in this project.

Another direction of this research focuses on the relationship between Heegaard Floer homology (specifically, of the "branched double-cover" of a knot), and another recently-defined using very different mathematical tools, called "Khovanov homology". In 2003, the PI in collaboration with Szabo showed the existence of an algebraic relationship between these two constructions, called a "spectral sequence". The present project uses bordered Floer homology to give an explicit, algorithmic computation of that spectral sequence.

In another direction, the project lead to a further algebraic structure on Heegaard Floer homology which lead to discovery of some new structures on the "concordance group", an object which was introduced in the study of knot theory. 

 


Last Modified: 04/24/2017
Modified by: Peter S Ozsvath
